Positive Reviews: It was my first stay at this very new accommodation which was chosen because of its location for a specific event I was attending in Tokyo.  It was perfect for that activity with good access to the Tokyo Metro system and hundreds of restaurants within a short walk in many directions. The room was well designed, a moderate size as with many Tokyo hotel rooms but not cramped either especially for one person. The storage space was minimal but sufficient for my basic essentials.  Instead of a flat screen TV, there was a video projector attached to the ceiling. With a little assistance from the technical staff at the hotel, I was able to stream video material from my iPhone and iPad on to the wall, a lightly textured grey paper but not affecting the brightness of the image significantly. Wifi worked well. A good shower with ample hot water. My room overlooked a fairly busy railway line which could be heard distantly during its working hours. If someone requires complete silence, perhaps a request for a room on the other side of the building could be suggested. Although I didn't try the food near the reception area of the hotel, I had a couple of meals in the Italian restaurant on the ground level and these were very good. In the neighbourhood were all manner of culinary treats from Japanese seafood to Spanish, Indian, Cantonese, Vietnamese and other cuisines. I look forward to another stay at this hotel. The room was a comfortable temperature at the end of Autumn. I could wash essential clothes and they would be dry within 24 hours, a very great consideration when travelling light.

I recently had the pleasure of staying at The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor, and I must say that it exceeded my expectations in more ways than one. The standout feature, undoubtedly, was the incredibly friendly and accommodating staff. Their warm welcome set the tone for a fantastic stay right from the beginning.

The hotel's location was another major highlight. Being within walking distance to numerous attractions and conveniently close to train stations made navigating the city a breeze. This strategic placement allowed me to explore the vibrant surroundings with ease and without the hassle of long commutes.

What truly impressed me was the array of dining options available within close proximity to the hotel. It's a food lover's paradise, with a multitude of eateries to choose from, offering a wide range of cuisines to suit every palate.

A remarkable aspect of The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor is their commitment to sustainability. The concept of providing guests with the option to take only what they need from the reception, thereby minimizing wastage, is both thoughtful and eco-conscious. This approach aligns perfectly with the values of modern travelers who prioritize responsible consumption.

Even the skincare products provided were of surprisingly high quality, a rarity in many hotels. It was evident that the hotel takes pride in providing guests with a comfortable and enjoyable experience down to the smallest details.

The convenience of having laundry facilities available on the premises was a game-changer, allowing me to travel light and still maintain clean clothes effortlessly. The affordability and ease of using the laundry facilities were greatly appreciated.

Upon arrival, we were pleasantly surprised to receive a voucher for a free welcome drink. This small gesture added a personalized touch to our stay and made us feel truly valued as guests.

Positive Reviews: We stayed at this hotel 3 times across our 3 week Japanese holiday (1 x 3 nights, 2 x 1 night), each time in a Moderate King Omiki Room. We found it to be really great for our needs for many reasons.  The rooms were wonderful - well, a bit strange as two were quite a bit more spacious (815 and 915) than the other one (808), but all perfectly adequate, scrupulously clean and well provisioned. Do-it-yourself Check In was easy and efficient. We didn't really use the bar or restaurant - we only redeemed our welcome drinks one time out of the three stays, as it's a bit restrictive as to what you can have and when. We did not find them intrusive in any way, and we also didn't have any issue with the trains nearby (we kinda like the sound of trains anyway). The block out blinds in the rooms are the best we've ever seen... you could literally sleep until midday and think it's 4am.  But the best part of all is the location - Ginza is (from what we can see) the best part of Tokyo for a tourist to stay. The food along the Corridor and elsewhere nearby provides so many amazing and great value options to sample the local cuisine (try Bistro Fukumimi across the road for one!). You can also stroll the wide boulevards at night and marvel at the brand label shops and funky architecture. We just loved Ginza. It's also easy to get to anywhere you want to with all the train stations and lines within a short walking distance (Yurakucho and Shimbashi on the JR line, plus Hibiya, Ginza, on other lines)... so easy if you are transferring to the Shinkansen at Tokyo only 1 stop from Yurakucho. It's also close (say, 20 min walk) to the wonderful Tsukiji Market and Hamariku Gardens. I would very much recommend The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor for your Tokyo base!

The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor is very well located, just 100 - 200 metres away from the Ginza shopping strips and several subway entrances. Our room was on the side street, which I think is a better location if you are worried about noise (and we were there on a Saturday and thought it was a very quiet area).  The rooms although small are larger than I expected, with a double bed in our case and a small sofa.  The bathroom was on the utilitarian side; functional, a bit like a phone booth, with a lovely shower rose!

Instead the staff went out of their way to try to understand our question and would bring in a more proficient English speaker if need be.  We needed to ask the front desk about storage of luggage after we checked out, as well as calling a cab for us when we needed to leave, and in each case they were very helpful, giving us clear, precise information. 

Overall, a very good value-for-money hotel!

Review Title: Ok for one or two nights, but no longer

The Royal Canvas, hotel Tokyo.  We had two rooms booked, one for our daughter Standard Double - Omiki, and one for my wife and I Moderate King - Prosecco, both rooms had queens size beds, ours the Moderate King - Prosecco was  a class above our daughter's thinking that we would get a better room, our room was slightly bigger but on the 6th floor, while our daughter was given the 8th floor.  As we were staying for 7 days on the second day we asked if we could change rooms for a quieter room, they said we could, but it would be a bigger room and there would be an extra cost, considering we had booked 2 rooms for 7 nights i was very surprised.

If you want to wash your clothes why you stay here, be prepared to stay in the hotel for 5 hours and on the drying cycle you need to go down a start the cycle every 30 minutes.

The hotel needs to decide if it wants to be a hotel or a night club, anyone arriving after 8pm when the night club is kicking off has to deal with the night club when checking in (both are in the same area)

Breakfast finished at 9.30am and the restaurant had to be vacated by 10am.

Breakfast is the same day after day, no variety to the food, except the little cup of soup.  So after 7 days i felt like it was back in the army easting daily rations.

I know many of you who stay here may find this place ok, but it’s totally inadequate for the price you pay.

I was not properly introduced to the payment system, neither guided to the reception or payment machine. I was SUPER JET-LAGGED and disoriented. I was confused when I came to the reception floor because the place looks more like a bar than a hotel. Note to those who come for work or want to rest after spending a day around Tokyo - this hotel is quite loud. They have parties at the reception floor every day (a different DJ comes). When I found my way to the machine I got stuck during the process and it took a while when someone came up and helped me. (I was the only customer, there were 4 people working at the front and it was evening) I admit that I was tired, because I came straight from a 14h flight where I couldn’t sleep. That’s why I wasn’t able to focus, was tired and clearly needed an assistance. I didn’t look my best and unfortunately a staff member who thought  I don’t speak Japanese had to comment on my appearance to her colleagues saying that I look scary. Never encountered this kind of rude comment from a staff member in Japan…

I came for work to Japan this time and expected a smooth check in and planned to straight go to sleep. Unfortunately it wasn’t the case. Paying such a high price my room didn’t even have a bath… (a standard in Japan) I admit that it was my mistake because I didn’t notice it at the time I reserved the place. Again, inadequate price for the room I got and service.

They give the same breakfast over and over again. Staff didn’t bother to put up glasses for drinks. Slowest service I’ve ever experienced in Japan. Had to skip most of the breakfast days even though I prepaid for it… (used 2 out of 6) When you stay in Japan, you get what you pay for but not in this hotel. I was here for work and every minute counted. It was a very simple breakfast that can be prepared quickly.
